div.head: "DOWN WITH DESPOTISM." RUSSIAN WORKMEN'S DEMONSTRATION. BRUTALITY OF COSSACKS.

div.p: A great demonstration of workmen has taken place here to protest against the brutality of the Cossacks. 50,000 men paraded the streets shouting, "Down with Despotism !" Suddenly the Cossacks and Dragoons rushed out of side Streets and, fired a volley on the crowd, which they dispersed. There were 18 killed and 100 wounded. (Reuter.)

37,000 Moslem insurgents are devastating Armenian villages in the Nakhitchevan district of the province of Erivan, and are committing terrible atrocities. One village repulsed the attack, killing 100. A force of troops besieged in another beat off the insurgents, and took 870 prisoners.5,000 Cossacks are proceeding from Baku to the troubled districts. (Reuter.)
Massacres and atrocities are reported from various localities of the Erivan province. (H.)
A Japanese detachment in the north of Korea completely occupied Kangsong last Tuesday. Some thousands of Russians, with artillery, retired towards Siou-song, 12 miles northward. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMAN STEAMER STOPPED BY RUSSIAN CRUISER.

div.p: The Russian cruiser "Dnieper" stopped the German S.S. "Prinz Sigisimund" to the North of Luzon on the 1st inst., and after haying examined her papers, permitted her to continue her course. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE PEACE NEGOTIATIONS. THE RUSSIAN PLENIPOTENTIARY.

div.p: M. Nelidoff has definitely been chosen as Russian plenipotentiary. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION. FRENCH NOTE TO GERMANY.

div.p: It is understood that M. Rouvier has handed a note to Prince Radolin, declaring that France is disposed to accept a conference with regard to Morocco, but she must first know the points which are to be considered. (Reuter.)
M. Rouvier has handed the note on Morocco to Prince Radolin. In this note M. Rouvier neither accepts nor declines the conference. He confines himself to setting forth the situation. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE ITALIAN NAVY. INCREASED ESTIMATES APPROVED.

div.p: The announcement that the Chamber had rejected the increased Navy Estimates was wrong ; as a matter of fact it approved them. (Havas.)

The negotiations with M. Ralli for the reconstruction of the Cabinet have failed, owing to the Ministers insisting on carrying out the programme of M. Delyannis unchanged. The ministers have resigned and M. Ralli is form-ing a new Cabinet A dissolution is probable. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE LOSS OF THE A8. DECISION OF COURT-MARTIAL.

div.p: The court-martial held on the survivors of the submarine A8 has decided that she foundered through an unexplained alteration in her buoyancy. It is regretted that the commanding officer did not stop the engine sooner, but the officers and survivors are acquitted and exonerated of all blame. (Reuter )

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON CROP. ESTIMATES OF YEILDS.

div.p: The reports of correspondents of the South ern Cotton Association indicate that the new crop will be 10,285;876 commercial bales. The leading American Bolls predict 9,500,000. (R)
The French Chamber has postponed the consideration of the increase in Custom dues (Reuter.)

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin records two fatal cases at Alexandria, the victims being a native workman at Kom el Shougafa and a Dative boy at Abou Choucha. Both cases were bubonic and the victims were found dead in their houses. A case is reported from Damanhour and a recovery from Mit Ghamr.

div.head: Eden Theatre
div.p: There was a large audience at this theatre last night to witness the marvellous performance by Prof. de Lafon-taine and his Creole mediums, the public being thoroughly mystified by the achievements of the latter. The entertainment consisted of mental suggestion and thought-reading, and is well worth a visit to the theatre. A second seance will be given on Sunday.

div.head: Fire at Tantah
div.p: At about 2.30 p.m. on Wednesday a fire broke out near Al Khan-street, Tantah. The fire brigade quickly appeared on the scene and under the able guidance of Amin Eff., Tantah city mulahiz,. succeeded in preventing any serious extension of the conflagration. As it was, the damage done probably amounts to £500. The Moudir of Gharbieh and the Mamour of Tantah arrived before the fire was got under, and helped in the work of extinguishing the flames. An enquiry failed to ascertain the cause of the outbreak, which was probably attributable to the practice of using so much dry stalk and weed in covering the wooden roofs of houses.

div.head: Fatal Motor Car Accident in Cairo
div.p: Between half-past twelve (midnight) and one o'olock on Wednesday morning a native woman was run over by the large motor-omnibus of the Brasseries des Pyramides in Cairo and killed. The omnibus was returning from its nightly excursion to Ghizeh and as it approached the corner of Boulac-street, which leads into Tewfikieh-square, a group of three native men and three women was observed, and they all appeared to be more or less in a state of intoxication. As the omnibus drew nearer one of the women went into the middle of the road and began to dance. The chauffeur immediately slowed down and tried to avoid running into her, but one of the lamps caught the woman's head and threw her down. The machine passed over her, killing her on the spot.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: A writer in the "Daily News" says "1 have been told that Lord Cromer is one of the most thorough students of the Bible whom we have among public men. Probably the Old Testament has a special interest for him, seeing that he has such a wide knowledge of Egypt Thirty-three years ago he became private secretary to the late Earl of Northbrook, and he was also a deep student of the Bible. One of Lord Northbrook's tasks in his later years was the publication of a small book entitled "The Teaching of Jesus Christ in His Own Words," which was intended to be a special help to the natives of India, for whose welfare he had such sympathy ever since he had held the office of Viceroy."

A marriage has been arranged, and will take p'ace at the end of this year, between Miss Marguerite Nungovich, eldest, daughter of George Nungovich Bey of Cairo, and Captain R. C. Wilson, R.A.M.C., son of R. J. Wilson, Esq., Dublin.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS. YESTERDAY'S DECISIONS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers was held yesterday at the San Stefano Casino, under the presidency of H. E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, the Regent.

Among other decisions come to was that concerning the increase of the fees at all the Government schools except the primary schools of Esneh, Edfou, and Assouan, and the redaction of the period of study at the secondary schools from four to three years. The fees in the primary schools will be raised from L.E. 5 to L.E. 6 for day scholars and L E. 8 to L.E. 10 for half-boarders. In the secondary schools the fees will be increased from L.E. 30 to L.E. 40 for boarders and from L.E. 20 to L.E. 25 for Mansourah school, from L.E. 15 to L.E.20 for the Khedivial Law School, and from L.E. 15 to L.E. 25 for the Sanieh school (boarders) and from L.E. 7 1/2 to L.E. 13 1/2 (day-scholars).

It was decided to suppress the primary education certificate and replace it by a certificate of aptitude for Government service. The minimum salary of Government employes in possession of superior diplomas was fixed at L.E. 12.
It was decided to convoke the provincial councils of Beni Souef and Minieh for the 2nd and 3rd July next, for the purpose of approving the creation of agricultural roads in these provinces.
It was decided to bring three professors from Europe (one French and two English) for the Khedivial Law School.
The note of the Ministry of Public Instruction asking for the addition of L.E. 40,000 to the budget for 1906 of this Department will be submitted to the next Cabinet Council.
The following decrees were passed :—
A decree with reference to the regulations as to the irrigation of 'Sharaki' which will be put into force immediately after insertion in the "Journal Officiel."
A decree referring to measures to be taken against rabies.

Decrees for the appropriation of land at Melig, Menoufieh, for the construction of the El Gori Masraf, and for prolonging the dyke from the Government Hospital to Wabour Hamza Boy El Tokhi at Mansourah, the dyke to be used as an agricultural road.

Other decrees deal with the modification of the regulations dealing with motors at Alexandria, the recognition of a company to be known as the "Financial and Commercial Company," and the construction of cemeteries in Dakahlieh and Behera provinces.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL LAW SCHOOL.
div.p: We learn from our Arabic contemporaries that the Ministry of Public Instruction, having great difficulty in finding a competent successor to Omar Bey Loutfi to teach the Penal Code in the Khedivial Law School, has decided that-the instruction on this subject shall henceforth be given in French and English.

div.head: A NEW BIG BUILDING PROJECT.
div.p: The Caisse Hypothecaire d'Egypte purchased a short time ago a property consisting of 20 feddans of land at Mahmashah, a suburb of Cairo situated at about one kilometre from the central station at Bab el-Hadid, a part of the land fronting the Ismailieh canal. The price paid was close upon £1,600 the feddan, or about P.T. 37 to P.T. 40 the square metre. The company has now laid out the whole property in plots for building and has made two fine boulevards and several streets through it Several of the sites have been sold at prices ranging from P.T. 45 to P.T. 120 per metre, so that when the whole of the plots are disposed of the company will have reaped a handsome profit on the investment. There is already a carriage road from the railway station to Mahmashah, but when the new Abbas boulevard is completed there will be another fine approach from that direction.
The place is considered exceedingly healthy, and it is likely to become a favorite residential suburb, on account of its proximity to the city.

div.head: WORK FOR THE NILE.
div.p: The success of the Assouan reservoir, which was completed in 1902, has turned people's attention to the question of the practicability of some comprehensive scheme which would settle the irrigation needs of Egypt once for all. The irrigable area of the country, according to "Engineering," is 6 1/4 million acres, and an ample supply of water is at hand in the Nile without diminishing the navigability of the river, provided that the superfluous flood-water is stored for use in the dry season. A quarter of a million acres lying along the edge of the deserts must remain only irrigated in flood time, as at present, as otherwise the desert sand would encroach upon the fertile valley. Four million acres are now perennially irrigated, and have an average value of 55l. par acre. The remaining two million acres remain to be dealt with.Two-thirds of this area are only irrigated in flood, and the remainder not irrigated at all. These two million acres have a mean value of 25l. per acre ; but if they were perennially irrigated their value would bo raised at once to 55l. per acre—an increase of 60,000,000l. in the wealth of the country.

div.head: THE MAHMAL ROBBERY. STORY OF THE THEFT.
div.p: The Parquet is still occupied with the Mahmal theft, and in the meantime specula tion is rife as to how the theft was committed It is supposed by many that this daring act of robbery was performed whilst the train was travelling from Cairo to Suez and that Androus Meloka leaped on to the foot board whilst the train was running at or about full-speed, broke the seals, opened the door with a master-key with which he had provided himself and having obtained his booty, jumped off again and re joined his accomplices. Such a supposition certainly lends colour to the telling of the story, and imparts to ita greater degree of sensationalism, but we are inclined to think that snob feats of agility are only performed by heroes of "penny-dreadfuls," and we would offer a much simpler and more probable solution to the problem of the mode of committal of the theft.

Before the train from which the money was stolen left for Suez it was drawn up at Abbassieh station, where it received its load of baggage, including the boxes of gold and papers. These boxes were placed at one end of the van in three rows of 7, 7, and 5, respectively, and two others were placed a little apart and to one side, one of these latter two containing tickets and papers and the other one £3,700 in gold. The doors of the van were locked and sealed, the train was shunted on to a parallel line, leaving another line between the train and the platform, and one solitary soldier was left to guard its treasure for the several hours which elapsed before its departure for Cairo. On one side of the train was this sentinel, on the other nothing but the wooden shanties of platelayers, and it was from this side that the entrance was effected. The thief had doubtless obtained a key of the van and therefore no difficulty presented itself : he had but to break the seal, open the door, and walk in ; so long as he did not disturb the sentinel, he was safe and had apparently no difficulty in performing his task in silence. When he had got inside the van he went about his work with cunning, and selected a box from the middle of the second row of seven, twisting the two adjacent boxes round so that they almost occupied the space of the three, and a cursory glance would not detect the fact that one box was missing.

Such is our solution of the way in which the theft was committed, and though we do not assert it as a positive fact, it is certainly the most probable solution, as well as the simplest The police themselves have not yet discovered where the robbery took place. The question naturally arises as to why one sentinel was left alone to guard a train containing such a sum of money, and why the authorities had not sufficient foresight to recognize that one man cannot keep watch over both sides of a train at the same time, and we ask these questions ourselves. Doubtless the van will be properly guarded in future years, but it is certainly a ease of locking the stable door after the mare has been stolen.

div.head: KAFR ZAYAT RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: Our Kafr Zayat Correspondent writes The accident at Tewfikieh is now known to have been caused by the carelessness of a gang. Orders had been given to the effect that two hours were to be spent on "renewing" the up line near Tewfikieh station and that the up and down lines were to be connected by a switch taking off Dear the bridge S. of the station. The foreman of the gang, after working on the down line near the bridge to get his points in, did not screw down the bolts properly. The down train tore up the track and appears to have actually crossed the bridge on the sleepers. Under the circumstances the escape of the passengers from a fall into the canal was literally providential.

div.head: LOCAL BREACH OF PROMISE CASE.
div.p: An action for breach of promise of marriage was decided yesterday at Cairo before the Tribunal Sommaire, presided over by Judge Wierdels. The plaintiff, a young French lady who keeps an establishment in the Sharia Manakh, sued a Belgian gentleman, an engineer, for breaking off a matrimonial engagement of some months' duration, and claimed one franc damages, assigning as a reason for the smallness of the sum that she merely wished to obtain judgment against her faithless lover and to let the world know of his base action.

The defendant, on receiving the citation of the court, had at once tendered the frano claimed through his lawyer, and offered to defray the lady's legal expenses, amounting to P.T. 150. The offer being indignantly declined the two sums were deposited at the greffier's office and the case was pleaded a fortnight ago, the plaintiff being represented by Maitre Guelhanmon, and the defendant by Maitre Neghib Ayoub, who in a long and able speech proved to the satisfaction of the Court that the young lady had sustained no prejudice, neither material nor moral, by the action of his client.
The presiding judge gave judgment for the defendant and condemned the young lady to pay costs. As the amount of the claim was only one franc there is no appeal against this decision.

div.head: ON THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: The methods of agriculture employed to Haurani folk are primitive enough but the soil, decomposed volcante rock, is excellent and only requires water to be productive. There is practically no irrigation in the whole district, and the farmers depend on the white and spring rains, which are usually heavy enough to ensure a good harvest in the summer. Last winter and the early spring of the present year were most favorable to the growers, though they were not in the least appreciated by the poor reservists who went down to Ma'an in open trucks.

From the tailboard of the carriage. I got a wide view of the country on both sides of the line. Here and there were rooky districts where grey boulders were scattered over the plain and thistles flourished. But as a rule the country was one great green expanse, flanked by low yellow hills on the side of the Jordan, by a formidable chain of black mountains to the east. At the foot of the range was a dark broken region that gradually neared the line. When we were within six or seven miles of it I could see that it was a chaotic maze of rooks and defiles, dull and black, barely dusted with green in a few areas where, I suppose, there were springs or water-holes. "That is the Leja," said the A.D.C., and added that the country was most difficult for campaigning— which was fairly obvious. He had taken part in the Druse war when fighting took place all over the Hauran and the Leja was the hiding place of large numbers of Druses, who inflicted heavy losses on the Ottoman troops before they had to succumb to forces that were much superior in strength. Their losses were very heavy—a large proportion of their fighting men being killed or wounded—but the women and children appear to have been little molest ed by the Turks proper, though I expect their Circassian and Bedouin auxiliaries were less humane.

Running in a south-easterly direction the railway soon neared the edge of the Leja. The contrast between the country on the east and west of the line was most remarkable. On one side the ground was covered with reefs and boulders for a couple of miles, and then the lava plateau rose some 50 feet above the plain and extended for miles eastward like a petrified sea.To the west lay the corn land stretching at least twenty miles, flat and green, its monotony only broken by an occasional village or one of the trim little red roofed stations of the French Damascus-Mzerib line. The villages-seemed substantial enough : they were built of black lava blocks instead of mud, and their walls were strong enough, if well defended, to repel attack. It is not so long since the Bedonint used to raid the villages of the Hauran plain; and the Druses, when they had a quarrel with the Government, were formidable neighbours for the fellaheen.

The Leja is a huge triangle, its apex pointing almost due north, its base line running some 30 miles from west to east. At Ezraa we reached its western basal angle, where the rocks and ravines ran right up to the railway, We had a short wait here and I was able to see something of the plateau : beyond the barracks of the Turkish battalion stationed here and the sombre black village, lay a maze of rock, seamed with gullies and depressions, broken here and there into deep clefts with precipitous sides. No country is better adapted for guerilla warfare : water exists in the Leja but it is hard to find : troops are ambushed in the ravines and are sniped at night from cliffs which they cannot scale, while the undulating broken ground enables even swordsmen to come to close quarters. Every army that has fought here has paid a heavy toll : even Ibrahim Pasha failed to reduce a few thousand Druses, and lost 12,000 men in the attempt, and it was only by the process of attrition that the Turks finally subjugated the district in the Hauran War.

Happily the relations between Druse and Turks are now improving, thanks to the conciliatory attitude of Nazim Pasha, the excellent Wali of Damascus, though the Druses continue to arm themselves with the best modern rifles to an extent that suggests the possibility of further trouble. (To be continued)

div.head: ARRIVAL OP BRITISH WARSHIPS.
div.p: The first-class armoured cruisers "Suffolk." Capt. Beath D.S.O. and "Lan aster," Capt. H Loftus Tottenham of the Essex" class arrived at Port Said this morning from Malta and are now coaling. It is uncertain how long they will stay or what their movements will be.

The former commander will be remembered as having been attached for some years to the Nile flotilla, and the latter as commanding the "Furious," which vessel was stationed here some time during last year.
The battleships, "Goliath" and "Canopus," homeward bound, are expected to arrive at Port Said next week, followed by four or five others from the China station.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: A VIS

La Municipalité met au concours un poste de médecin-hygiéniste, inspecteur des é ablissements insalubres et des denrées alimentaires de la classe de 35 à 40 L.E. par mois avec le traitement minimum pour commencer.

Toate personne qui désirerait prendre part au concours est priée de présenter une demande avant le 20 juillet 1905, dernier délai, et de remettre en même temps ses diplômes ainsi que tout document constatant ses connaissances spéciales en matière d'hygiène, et son certificat de noissance. Alexandrie, le 22 juin 1905.
